dt: {bc}to change course by turning the stern to the wind

pt: {sc}swerve{/sc} {sc}veer{/sc} {sc}deviate{/sc} {sc}depart{/sc} {sc}digress{/sc} {sc}diverge{/sc} mean to turn aside from a straight course. {sc}swerve{/sc} may suggest a physical, mental, or moral turning away from a given course, often with abruptness.
{sc}veer{/sc} implies a major change in direction.

pt.t: at that point the path {it}veers{/it} to the right

pt: {sc}deviate{/sc} implies a turning from a customary or prescribed course.
{sc}depart{/sc} suggests a deviation from a traditional or conventional course or type.
{sc}digress{/sc} applies to a departing from the subject of one's discourse.
{sc}diverge{/sc} may equal {sc}depart{/sc} but usually suggests a branching of a main path into two or more leading in different directions.

et: Middle English {it}veren{/it}, probably altered from Anglo-French {it}virer{/it} "to whirl, turn, revolve" (continental Old French, "to throw with a twisting motion"), going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*vīrāre{/it}, reduced from Latin {it}vibrāre{/it} "to wave, propel suddenly" {ma}{mat|vibrate|}{/ma}

The vowel change ({it}e{/it} in Middle English, {it}i{/it} in French) is of unclear motivation. Cf. Old Scots {it}wyr, wyre{/it} "to throw along a curving trajectory," {it}vyre{/it} "to turn about a fixed point," apparently borrowed from Anglo-French {it}virer{/it} with no alteration of vowel.
shortdef: to shift in a clockwise direction
to change course by turning the stern to the wind
a change in course or direction

shortdef: to let out (something, such as a rope)
